sen.j: 烏帽子（えぼし）とは平安時代から近代にかけて和装での礼服着装の際に成人男性が被った帽子のこと。
sen.e: Eboshi is a headwear which an adult man put on when he wore a Japanese formal dress from the Heian period to modern times.
Eboshi was the headwear which an adult man put on when he wore a Japanese formal attire from the Heian period to modern times.
sen.cmt: is a→was the,formal dress→formal attire と修正しました。
sen.e: Eboshi was the headwear which an adult man put on when he wore a Japanese formal attire from the Heian period to modern times.

sen.j: 初期は薄い絹で仕立てたものだったが、のちに黒漆を塗った紙製に変わる。
sen.e: In the early days eboshi had been tailored from thin silk, but later it changed to paper coated with black lacquer.

sen.j: 衣装の格式や着装者の身分によっていくつかの種類があり、厳格に使い分けた。
sen.e: There were several kinds of eboshis according to the formality of garments and the social status of the wearer, and the proper one was strictly chosen to use.
There were several kinds of eboshi according to the formality of garments and the social status of the wearer, and the proper one was strictly chosen to apply.

sen.j: 正装の際にかぶる冠より格式が落ち、平安から室町にかけては普段着に合わせて着装した。
sen.e: The formality of the eboshi was lower than that of the court cap worn with formal attire, and the eboshi was worn with casual dress from the Heian period to the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 本来男性用であるが白拍子など女性が被る場合もある。
sen.e: Eboshi is originally for men, but sometimes worn by women including Shirabyoushi (a woman who plays Japanese traditional Shirabyoushi dance).
sen.cmt: 2つめの"Shirabyoushi"（踊りとしての「白拍子」）の説明である"Japanese traditional dance"は、()に入れるのではなく、文中に入れ込みました。
sen.e: Eboshi is originally for men, but sometimes worn by women including Shirabyoshi (a woman who performs Japanese traditional Shirabyoushi dance).

sen.j: 近代になると烏帽子を固定する髷がなくなったため、頭にすっぽりとかぶり掛緒を顎にかけて固定するタイプのものが用いられることが多い。
sen.e: In modern times, the mobling type of eboshi fixed at the chin with a kakeo strap is used often because a mage (chignon) to fix an eboshi has been abolished.
In modern times, the type of eboshi, completely covers the head which is fixed at the chin with the kakeo strap is used often, because the mage (chignon) to fix the eboshi has been abolished.
sen.cmt: ”頭にすっぽりとかぶり”という部分を修正しました。カンマを挿入しました。カッコ, a, an を修正しました。
sen.e: In modern times, the type of eboshi, completely covers the head which is fixed at the chin with the kakeo strap is used often, because the mage (chignon) to fix the eboshi has been abolished.

sen.j: 大相撲の行司が着用しているのを見ることができる。
sen.e: We can see it worn by a gyoji (umpire) of the grand sumo tournament.
We can see it worn by a gyoji (referee) of the grand sumo tournament.
sen.cmt: カッコを修正しました。umpire→referee （referee での訳出のほうがウェブ上多かったのと、umpire は”審判委員”のことを指すことがあるので、このように修正しました）
sen.e: We can see it worn by a gyoji (referee) of the grand sumo tournament.

sen.e: Eboshi-oya (a person who puts an eboshi on a young man's head on his ceremony of attaining manhood)/Eboshi-go (a person who is put an eboshi on his head on his ceremony of attaining manhood)

sen.j: 武家の元服の儀式で新成人（烏帽子子）の後見人を勤める者を「烏帽子親」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The person who acts as a guardian for a new adult (eboshi-go) at samurai family's ceremony of attaining manhood is called "eboshi-oya."
sen.cmt: 「」はシングルクオーテーションで対応するよう仕様書に指示がありましたが、用語統一リスト.xls内に、用語の説明はダブルクオーテーションでとの記載がありましたので、そちらに従いました。
sen.e: The person who takes the role as a guardian for a new adult (eboshi-go) at samurai family's ceremony of attaining manhood is called "eboshi-oya."

sen.j: 平安時代の初冠の儀に由来するものである。
sen.e: This tradition originates from the uikoburi ritual (putting a crown on a young man's head on the ceremony of attaining manhood) of the Heian period.

sen.j: 宮中の位階を持つ貴族が冠を着用するのに対して烏帽子を持ち出したのが由来。
sen.e: The origin is that samurai families introduced the eboshi while the nobles with Ikai (court rank) of imperial court wore court caps.

sen.j: どちらにしてもこの日を境に男性は頭に冠や烏帽子をかぶり大人社会に迎えられる。
sen.e: In either case a man put a court cap or an eboshi on the head and was received into adult society from that day.

sen.j: ちなみに平安時代の子供が遊びの中で大人を真似て烏帽子の代わりに額に結わえつけた三角の布が、後代死者の威儀を正すために死装束に加えられた。
sen.e: Incidentally, a triangle-shaped cloth which children tied to their forehead instead of the eboshi to imitate adults during their play in the Heian period was added to a shroud in later ages to dignify the dead.

sen.j: ただし、色のみ黒ではなく死装束の色である白に変わっている。
